bibliography.source_title: Disentangling fine particles (PM2.5) composition in Hanoi, Vietnam: Combined PMF analysis of filter and ACSM measurements
bibliography.source_authors: Dominutti, P.A., Cohen, D.D., Stelcer, E., et al.
bibliography.key_findings: Source apportionment study identifying traffic (10-15%), industry (10-15%), coal combustion (10-15%), biomass burning (15-20%), and secondary aerosols (30-40%) as major PM2.5 sources in Hanoi. Vietnam experienced 11% annual growth in coal consumption 2011-2021.

bibliography.source_title: Impact of Covid-19 partial lockdown on PM2.5, SO2, NO2, O3, and trace elements in PM2.5 in Hanoi, Vietnam
bibliography.source_authors: Nguyen, T.P.M., Bui, T.H., Nguyen, M.K., et al.
bibliography.key_findings: COVID-19 lockdown reduced NO2 by 75.8%, PM2.5 by 55.9%, SO2 by 60.7%. Traffic identified as major mobile source. Industrial activities (stationary sources) remained stable during lockdown. Motorbike exhaust is major NO2 source.

bibliography.source_title: Emission factors of selected air pollutants from rice straw burning in Hanoi, Vietnam
bibliography.source_authors: Pham, C.T., Ly, B.T., Nghiem, T.D., et al.
bibliography.key_findings: Rice straw open burning (RSOB) emission factors: PM2.5 = 34.0 ± 17.6 g/kg rice straw. Annual emissions in Hanoi: 10.8 Gg PM2.5, 0.67 Gg SO2, 0.35 Gg NO2, 13.7 Gg CO. Higher than Thailand and China.

bibliography.source_title: Chemical characterization, source apportionment, and human health risk assessment of PM2.5 in an urban area in Hanoi, Vietnam
bibliography.source_authors: Bui, T.H., Nguyen, D.L., Nguyen, T.P.M., et al.
bibliography.key_findings: PCA+EF analysis identified major PM2.5 sources: non-exhaust traffic emission and crustal dust, exhaust traffic emission, coal combustion, and industrial source. Al, Fe, Pb, Zn account for 85-89% of trace elements.

bibliography.source_title: Assessing the Impact of Traffic Emissions on Fine Particulate Matter and Carbon Monoxide Levels in Hanoi through COVID-19 Social Distancing Periods
bibliography.source_authors: Le, N.H., Ly, B.T., Thai, P.K., et al.
bibliography.key_findings: Traffic primary emissions reduced 37-60% for PM2.5 and 33-49% for CO during social distancing. CO at traffic sites was double urban sites. PM2.5 reduced 14-18% during lockdown. Coal-fired power plants remained stable.

bibliography.source_title: Chemical composition and potential sources of PM2.5 in Hanoi
bibliography.source_authors: Makkonen, U., Vestenius, M., Huy, L.N., et al.
bibliography.key_findings: PMF analysis: Traffic 12%, Local SIA 18%, Biomass burning 19%, Industry 9%, Long-range transported SIA 25%, Dust 17%. Half of PM2.5 is organic matter (40% from biomass burning). One third is secondary inorganic aerosol dominated by sulphate (coal combustion indicator).

bibliography.source_title: Air Quality in Hanoi: Current Situation & Policy Intervention
bibliography.source_authors: The World Bank & Hanoi Department of Natural Resources & Environment
bibliography.key_findings: Primary PM2.5 sources in Hanoi: Industrial activities 29%, Open burning of rice straw 26%, Road dust 23%, Transport 15%. Only one third of PM2.5 from local sources; rest transported from Greater Hanoi, Red River Delta, other provinces.

contradictions.conflicting_evidence: Các nghiên cứu đưa ra tỷ lệ đóng góp khác nhau: 12% (Makkonen 2023), 15% (World Bank 2021), 10-15% (Dominutti 2024). Sự khác biệt do phương pháp source apportionment và thời gian nghiên cứu khác nhau.

Đóng góp của biomass burning dao động từ 15% (GAINS model) đến 26% (emission inventory) đến 19% (PMF). Sự khác biệt do định nghĩa biomass burning (chỉ rice straw vs tất cả biomass) và phương pháp đánh giá.
